To you as a student chemical engineer, what does this statement bring
to mind:
Nearly two-thirds of Du Pont's current sales are in products entirely
or virtually unknown in 1930.
Likely it suggests years of solving
intriguing engineering problems, the
designing of unique equipment, the
carrying out of reactions under extraordinary conditions.
But it should also suggest the opportunities that will come to chemical engineers in the future. For at
Du Pont, new and better products
are continually being developed.
From today's extended program of
fundamental research you can expect
more neoprenes, more nylons, more
plastics like "Teflon" tetrafluoroethylene resin.
As these products come out of the
laboratory,they will bring with them
a succession of interesting and challenging problems for the chemical
engineer. Problems that will arise
out of their very newness.
For instance, take nylon, the first

wholly synthetic organic fiber. In
working out techniques for its commercial manufacture, there was
practically nothing to go on. The
compounds of which it was made,
hex'amethylenediamine and adipic
acid, were essentially laboratory
chemicals. Processes had to be devised to make them from cheap raw
materials—benzene, hydrogen, air
and ammonia. Large-scale preparation of nylon salt from amine and
acid required going beyond the classical unit operations.
Here for the first time it was proposed to extrude a fiber with extreme
accuracy from a melted polymer at
290°C. At this temperature the polymer decomposes slowly. It had to be
melted, pumped at 5000 p.s.i. pressure through microscopic holes and4
cooled in a hurry. Otherwise the fiber
would emerge discolored.
The Du Pont chemical and mechanical engineers and other men
and women who worked with them
ran into one difficulty after another.
Morethan once they thought that the

project would have to be abandoned.
However, it is basic in Du Pont
people's philosophy not only to take
on difficult pioneering problems, but
to see them through. With nylon,
this persistence paid off handsomely.
Is this the kind of problem you'd
like to attack, the kind of people
you'd like to work with?

THE HIGHEST PLANE
The Honor Commission announced fills week that it would
plan whereby undergraduates would become
more conscious of the Honor System at Johns Hopkins.
Their program which asks that each student, upon completing
an examination, compose a short signed statement to the effect
that he has abided by the rules of the system seems to be an
improved method of keeping the Honor System before the students.
However, at first, as in all new plans, there will be those who will
object, calling it "immature", "childlike", those who will regularly forget to follow this request, and those who will sign
without understanding the true meaning of their words.
Nevertheless it is expected that the greater majority of students will sign statements understandingly and will then be
not only more conscious of the meaning of the Honor System themselves but also more observant of fellow students who may be
suspected of cheating.
Shou1,1 someone suspect or observe anuother cheating, he
should stand up in classand draw the attention of the group to the
fact that all tests are conducted under the Honor Code. If this
action fails to retard the suspected cheater he should be reported
to the Commission. An Honor System will never be successful
as long as one student allows another to cheat without at least
reporting the incident.
In order to have this new system work smoothly, instructors
and others conducting tests must, at first, remind students that
the new program is in effect. They themselves must also stand
firmly behind the foundations of the Honor Plan Or their reminders shall serve to defeat the whole program.
•
Insincerity or cynicism on behalf of instructors and others
whom students respect will only weaken the plan.
Possibly the greatest fallacy in this plan would be' that
soon a trite statement would follow each exam paper. Students
would be signing an honor pledge through habit, not through
sincere awareness.
The strength of the Honor Commission lies completely in the
hands of the students. If this new plan is to work successfully
everyone must cooperate in, at least, the realization that the
forced and enforced moral action of an honor eode carried out
on one's own part is the lesser of evils means of upholding justice
and fairness.

CONFERENCE IN THE CLOUDS
Among the undergraduates on any college campus, you'll find
the talk reaching up to the clouds. And once in a while — in a classroom, around a study table, or even in a bull session — a really big
idea is born.
Big ideas come, too, from the men and women in laboratories,
business offices, shops. But often these professionals are exploring
a path first glimpsed in college.
How do we know? Because of the many college people who
have come into the Bell System, where big ideas and a lot of dreams
have taken their place in progress. The human voice, carried along
a wire, first across a town, then a state, a nation, and now the world.
Music and pictures and things happening delivered into cities and
hamlets all across the land by radicand television networks.
We're always looking for the men and women who get big
ideas—whether they're about people, or machines, or ways of doing
things. It's the only way the Bell System can keep on giving this
country the best telephone service in the world.

NCAA Attempts Major Revisions
By STEVE PASSERMAN
Cincinnatti last week was the
site of the annual NCAA meeting
and due to the irregularities
found in the athletic policies of
several schools recently the usually placid gathering took on a
new significance.
The major interest at the meeting centered around the recommendations made by a committee
of college presidents who were
asked by the American Council
for Education (ACE) to study
collegiate athletics at the present
time.
Although the recommendations
were still not in their final form,
the sweeping list of proposals disclosed by Dr. John Hannah, President of Michigan State College
and chairman of .the President's
Committee, gave the NCAA repTesentatives an idea of what has
been going on in the ACE.
These proposals which would
change many of the practices now
common in college sports included:
1. That the giving of scholarships should be based solely on

the students educational ability
and financial need. This aid would
be limited to tuition, lodging,
board, and books. All scholarship
requests by would-be athletes
must travel through the same
channels as any other scholarship
request.
2. That practices and games in
football, basketball, and baseball
be limited to their specific seasons.
In football this would mean
nothing before September 1 and
no activity later than the first
Saturday in December. It would
eliminate all post-season games.
Basketball and baseball dates
woud be December 1 to March 15
and March 1 to commencement
respectively.
3. That neither freshmen nor
transfer students be allowed to
play on varsity teams. The freshmen, in order to get adjusted to
their new surroundings should
compete in a schedule of their
own, and the transferees should
have one year of residence before
being eligible to compete on a
varsity team.
recommendations, after
The

being drafted in their final form,
must then be presented to the executive committee of the ACE before any further steps can be
taken.
Athletic
Director
Marshall
Turner, representing Johns Hopkins at the conference has been
working together with Mr. Heimer of Gettysburg on a survey of
the various athletic policies of
the smaller colleges.
The results of the survey
though not yet complete, show
that the great majority of smaller
institutions operate at a deficit.
Also at these schools it has been
found that the physical education
instruction is co-ordinated with intercollegiate sports, while at the
larger universities a system of
athletic associations is used.
Mr. Turner feels that the NCAA
and the President's Committee
both are anxious to straighten
out the athletic situation. He
feels the Cincinnati conclave was
satisfactory, but regrets only that
the
of
recommendations
the
President's Committee were not
presented in their final form.

With Marshall Turner attending
the N.C.A.A. meeting in Cincinnati, young Mr. Margolis took over
the reins and made his coaching
premiere a successful one. In fact,
he added some contributions which
are unique for a Hopkins coach,
such as scoring fifteen points to
lead both squads and several times
dribbling the length of the floor
to score.
Two impressive newcomers were
the rapidly improving sophomores,
George Klemmick and Bob Evans.
Klemmick tallied thirteen points,
second only to his coach, and
Evans tallied eight, while playing
another fine rebound game.
Klemmick Hurt
Kleminick's improvement, however, was retarded early in the
third quarter when he aggravated
an old football injury to his knee.
The torn ligaments were twisted
out of place, and he had to be
helped from the court. He may
return to action tomorrow night.
Joe Della Ratta, C.U.'s muchheralded star, had one of his
worse nieits, scoring a mere thirteen p9ints. He was restrained by
close guarding by Klemmick and
Ed Chvatal. And, of course, Mone
Margolis. Toni Brown, a lanky
(Continued on Page 8)

Basketball
(Continued from Page 7)
forward with a good hook shot,
tallied ten points.,
golds Early Lead
Unlike Hopkins' other wins,
where they spurted and slumped
by turns, this time they took an
early lead and just kept stretching
It. Klemmick's set gave them a
14-13 lead, which they increased to
22-17 at the end of the quarter
and 43-28 at halftime.
When it reached 63-34 Coach
Margolis ran in the reserves until
he cleared the bench. The score
reached 68-37 before the hapless
visitors cut it to its final reading,
72-48. All members of the squad
saw action except Al Birtch, who
is currently on the injured list.
Among those seeing action for
the first time were Doug Dayton
and Elliot Labiner, who had previously been sidelined by injuries.
The most impressive of the reserves were Jim Williamson and
Howard Schwartz.
The game also marked the first
home appearance of six-foot,eightinch Bob Rutherford. The crowd
reserved its loudest applause for
"Tiny" when he swished his first
basket of the season.

To you as a student chemical engineer, what does this statement bring
to mind:
Nearly two-thirds of Du Pont's current sales are in products entirely
or virtually unknown in 1930.
Likely it suggests years of solving
intriguing engineering problems, the
designing of unique equipment, the
carrying out of reactions under extraordinary conditions.
But it should also suggest the opportunities that will come to chemical engineers in the future. For at
Du Pont, new and better products
are continually being developed.
From today's extended program of
fundamental research you can expect
more neoprenes, more nylons, more
plastics like "Teflon" tetrafluoroethylene resin.
As these products come out of the
laboratory,they will bring with them
a succession of interesting and challenging problems for the chemical
engineer. Problems that will arise
out of their very newness.
For instance, take nylon, the first

wholly synthetic organic fiber. In
working out techniques for its commercial manufacture, there was
practically nothing to go on. The
compounds of which it was made,
hex'amethylenediamine and adipic
acid, were essentially laboratory
chemicals. Processes had to be devised to make them from cheap raw
materials—benzene, hydrogen, air
and ammonia. Large-scale preparation of nylon salt from amine and
acid required going beyond the classical unit operations.
Here for the first time it was proposed to extrude a fiber with extreme
accuracy from a melted polymer at
290°C. At this temperature the polymer decomposes slowly. It had to be
melted, pumped at 5000 p.s.i. pressure through microscopic holes and4
cooled in a hurry. Otherwise the fiber
would emerge discolored.
The Du Pont chemical and mechanical engineers and other men
and women who worked with them
ran into one difficulty after another.
Morethan once they thought that the

project would have to be abandoned.
However, it is basic in Du Pont
people's philosophy not only to take
on difficult pioneering problems, but
to see them through. With nylon,
this persistence paid off handsomely.
Is this the kind of problem you'd
like to attack, the kind of people
you'd like to work with?

THE HIGHEST PLANE
The Honor Commission announced fills week that it would
plan whereby undergraduates would become
more conscious of the Honor System at Johns Hopkins.
Their program which asks that each student, upon completing
an examination, compose a short signed statement to the effect
that he has abided by the rules of the system seems to be an
improved method of keeping the Honor System before the students.
However, at first, as in all new plans, there will be those who will
object, calling it "immature", "childlike", those who will regularly forget to follow this request, and those who will sign
without understanding the true meaning of their words.
Nevertheless it is expected that the greater majority of students will sign statements understandingly and will then be
not only more conscious of the meaning of the Honor System themselves but also more observant of fellow students who may be
suspected of cheating.
Shou1,1 someone suspect or observe anuother cheating, he
should stand up in classand draw the attention of the group to the
fact that all tests are conducted under the Honor Code. If this
action fails to retard the suspected cheater he should be reported
to the Commission. An Honor System will never be successful
as long as one student allows another to cheat without at least
reporting the incident.
In order to have this new system work smoothly, instructors
and others conducting tests must, at first, remind students that
the new program is in effect. They themselves must also stand
firmly behind the foundations of the Honor Plan Or their reminders shall serve to defeat the whole program.
•
Insincerity or cynicism on behalf of instructors and others
whom students respect will only weaken the plan.
Possibly the greatest fallacy in this plan would be' that
soon a trite statement would follow each exam paper. Students
would be signing an honor pledge through habit, not through
sincere awareness.
The strength of the Honor Commission lies completely in the
hands of the students. If this new plan is to work successfully
everyone must cooperate in, at least, the realization that the
forced and enforced moral action of an honor eode carried out
on one's own part is the lesser of evils means of upholding justice
and fairness.

CONFERENCE IN THE CLOUDS
Among the undergraduates on any college campus, you'll find
the talk reaching up to the clouds. And once in a while — in a classroom, around a study table, or even in a bull session — a really big
idea is born.
Big ideas come, too, from the men and women in laboratories,
business offices, shops. But often these professionals are exploring
a path first glimpsed in college.
How do we know? Because of the many college people who
have come into the Bell System, where big ideas and a lot of dreams
have taken their place in progress. The human voice, carried along
a wire, first across a town, then a state, a nation, and now the world.
Music and pictures and things happening delivered into cities and
hamlets all across the land by radicand television networks.
We're always looking for the men and women who get big
ideas—whether they're about people, or machines, or ways of doing
things. It's the only way the Bell System can keep on giving this
country the best telephone service in the world.

play

To assist outstanding BS graduates in
obtaining their Master of Science Degrees while employed in industry and
making a significant contribution to
important military work.
ELIGIBILITY

June 1952 graduates receiving BS Degrees in the following fields:
Electrical Engineering
Electronic Engineering
Physics
Mechanical Engineering
Aeronautical Engineering
Those chosen to participate in this plan
will be from the upper portion of their
graduating classes or will have evidenced unusual technical ability. They
must also have evidenced imaginative
ability and possess personality traits
enabling them to work well with others.
CITIZENSHIP

Applicants must be United States citizens who can be cleared for "Secret,"
due to their work at Hughes Research
and Development Laboratories being of
a classified nature.
PARTICIPATING UNIVERSITIES

The University of California at Los
Angeles and the University of Southern
California will participate in this program, and candidates for Master of
Science Degrees must meet entrance requirements for advanced study at these
schools.

Under this Cooperative Plan, starting
June 1952, the following schedule of
employment at Hughes is arranged:
Full time—from June 1952 to Sept. 1952
Half time—from Sept.1952toJune 1953
Full time—from June 1953 toSept.1953
Half time—from Sept.1953toJune 1954
Under this arrangement it is possible
for a recipient to receive nth of a normal year's salary each year and to attend

a university half time during regular
sessions working on his Master's Degree.
SALARIES

Salaries will be commensurate with the
individual's ability and experience and
reflect the average in the electronics industry. Salary growth will be on the
same basis as full-time members of the
engineering staff. In addition, the indi-.
viduals will be eligible for health, accident, and life insurance benefits, as
well as other benefits accruing to fulltime members.
TRAVEL AND MOVING EXPENSES

For those residing outside of the Southern California area, actual travel and
moving expenses will be allowed up to
10% of the full starting annual salary.
TUITION

Tuition at either UCLA or USC,covering the required number of units necessary to obtain a Master's Degree, will
be paid by Hughes Research and Development Laboratories.
NUMBER OF AWARDS

Approximately one hundred Cooperative Awards shall be made each year, if
sufficient qualified candidates present
themselves.
SELECTION OF CANDIDATES

Candidates will be selected by a coin.
mittee of representation composed of
two each from the University of California at Los Angeles, the University of
Southern California,and the Hughes Research and Development Laboratories.
DATES FOR APPLYING

Informal applications should be mailed
prior to January 30, 1952. The Laboratories will then forward formal applications, which should be returned,
accompanied by up-to-date grade transcripts, by February 15, 1952.Selections

March.

NCAA Attempts Major Revisions
By STEVE PASSERMAN
Cincinnatti last week was the
site of the annual NCAA meeting
and due to the irregularities
found in the athletic policies of
several schools recently the usually placid gathering took on a
new significance.
The major interest at the meeting centered around the recommendations made by a committee
of college presidents who were
asked by the American Council
for Education (ACE) to study
collegiate athletics at the present
time.
Although the recommendations
were still not in their final form,
the sweeping list of proposals disclosed by Dr. John Hannah, President of Michigan State College
and chairman of .the President's
Committee, gave the NCAA repTesentatives an idea of what has
been going on in the ACE.
These proposals which would
change many of the practices now
common in college sports included:
1. That the giving of scholarships should be based solely on

the students educational ability
and financial need. This aid would
be limited to tuition, lodging,
board, and books. All scholarship
requests by would-be athletes
must travel through the same
channels as any other scholarship
request.
2. That practices and games in
football, basketball, and baseball
be limited to their specific seasons.
In football this would mean
nothing before September 1 and
no activity later than the first
Saturday in December. It would
eliminate all post-season games.
Basketball and baseball dates
woud be December 1 to March 15
and March 1 to commencement
respectively.
3. That neither freshmen nor
transfer students be allowed to
play on varsity teams. The freshmen, in order to get adjusted to
their new surroundings should
compete in a schedule of their
own, and the transferees should
have one year of residence before
being eligible to compete on a
varsity team.
recommendations, after
The

being drafted in their final form,
must then be presented to the executive committee of the ACE before any further steps can be
taken.
Athletic
Director
Marshall
Turner, representing Johns Hopkins at the conference has been
working together with Mr. Heimer of Gettysburg on a survey of
the various athletic policies of
the smaller colleges.
The results of the survey
though not yet complete, show
that the great majority of smaller
institutions operate at a deficit.
Also at these schools it has been
found that the physical education
instruction is co-ordinated with intercollegiate sports, while at the
larger universities a system of
athletic associations is used.
Mr. Turner feels that the NCAA
and the President's Committee
both are anxious to straighten
out the athletic situation. He
feels the Cincinnati conclave was
satisfactory, but regrets only that
the
of
recommendations
the
President's Committee were not
presented in their final form.

With Marshall Turner attending
the N.C.A.A. meeting in Cincinnati, young Mr. Margolis took over
the reins and made his coaching
premiere a successful one. In fact,
he added some contributions which
are unique for a Hopkins coach,
such as scoring fifteen points to
lead both squads and several times
dribbling the length of the floor
to score.
Two impressive newcomers were
the rapidly improving sophomores,
George Klemmick and Bob Evans.
Klemmick tallied thirteen points,
second only to his coach, and
Evans tallied eight, while playing
another fine rebound game.
Klemmick Hurt
Kleminick's improvement, however, was retarded early in the
third quarter when he aggravated
an old football injury to his knee.
The torn ligaments were twisted
out of place, and he had to be
helped from the court. He may
return to action tomorrow night.
Joe Della Ratta, C.U.'s muchheralded star, had one of his
worse nieits, scoring a mere thirteen p9ints. He was restrained by
close guarding by Klemmick and
Ed Chvatal. And, of course, Mone
Margolis. Toni Brown, a lanky
(Continued on Page 8)

Basketball
(Continued from Page 7)
forward with a good hook shot,
tallied ten points.,
golds Early Lead
Unlike Hopkins' other wins,
where they spurted and slumped
by turns, this time they took an
early lead and just kept stretching
It. Klemmick's set gave them a
14-13 lead, which they increased to
22-17 at the end of the quarter
and 43-28 at halftime.
When it reached 63-34 Coach
Margolis ran in the reserves until
he cleared the bench. The score
reached 68-37 before the hapless
visitors cut it to its final reading,
72-48. All members of the squad
saw action except Al Birtch, who
is currently on the injured list.
Among those seeing action for
the first time were Doug Dayton
and Elliot Labiner, who had previously been sidelined by injuries.
The most impressive of the reserves were Jim Williamson and
Howard Schwartz.
The game also marked the first
home appearance of six-foot,eightinch Bob Rutherford. The crowd
reserved its loudest applause for
"Tiny" when he swished his first
basket of the season.
